name: Three Minimums
statement: Given a list of distinct values, we denote with first minimum , second minimum , and third minimum the three smallest values (in increasing order). A permutation $$$p_1, p_2, \dots, p_n$$$ is good if the following statement holds for all pairs $$$(l,r)$$$ with $$$1\le l < l+2 \le r\le n$$$. If $$$\{p_l, p_r\}$$$ are (not necessarily in this order) the first and second minimum of $$$p_l, p_{l+1}, \dots, p_r$$$ then the third minimum of $$$p_l, p_{l+1},\dots, p_r$$$ is either $$$p_{l+1}$$$ or $$$p_{r-1}$$$. You are given an integer $$$n$$$ and a string $$$s$$$ of length $$$m$$$ consisting of characters " < " and " > ". Count the number of good permutations $$$p_1, p_2,\dots, p_n$$$ such that, for all $$$1\le i\le m$$$, $$$p_i < p_{i+1}$$$ if $$$s_i =$$$ " < "; $$$p_i > p_{i+1}$$$ if $$$s_i =$$$ " > ". As the result can be very large, you should print it modulo $$$998\,244\,353$$$.
inputFormat: The first line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$2 \le n \le 2 \cdot 10^5$$$, $$$1 \leq m \leq \min(100, n-1)$$$). The second line contains a string $$$s$$$ of length $$$m$$$, consisting of characters " < " and " > ".
outputFormat: Print a single integer: the number of good permutations satisfying the constraints described in the statement, modulo $$$998\,244\,353$$$.
